facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 971 of 1973 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal, No. 971 of 1973.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 1st June 1973 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in W. No. 1949 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 1st June, 1973 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in W. No. 1949 of 1972.

facts.text: The respondent Karibasappa was the President of the Bellary District Co-operative Central Bank Limited, Hospet.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Karibasappa was the President of the Bellary District Co-operative Central Bank Limited, Hospet.

facts.text: Karibasappa challenged two notifications dated 11 August 1972 issued by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: He challenged two numberifications dated 11 August, 1972 issued by the State Government.

facts.text: Notifications issued under sections 54 and 121 of the Mysore Co-operative Societies Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The numberifications were issued in exercise of the, powers companyferred by sections 54 and 121 Of the Mysore Co-operative Societies Act, 1959 hereinafter

facts.text: Management of the Bank conducted by Committee consisting of President, Vice-President, ten elected members and certain nominees of State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The management and administration of the Bank was companyducted by the Committee companysisting of the President, the Vice- President, and ten elected members from various companystituencies and certain

facts.text: Government nominated more than three persons as its representatives.

anchor.surface_text: numberinees of the State Government. At numbertime the Government numberinated more then three persons as its representatives.

facts.text: Bank had share capital of Rs. 75 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank had a share capital of Rs. 75 lakhs.

facts.text: State Government contributed Rs. 23.8 lakhs to the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companytributed Rs.23.8 lakhs.

facts.text: Reserve Bank of India advanced a loan of Rs. 135 lakhs to the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The Reserve Bank of India advanced a loan of Rs. 135 lakhs.

facts.text: Apex Bank gave a loan of Rs. 200 lakhs to the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The Apex Bank also gave a loan of Rs. 200 lakhs

facts.text: State Government guaranteed repayment of loans to Reserve Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government guaranteed the repayment of loans to the Reserve Bank of India.

facts.text: Reserve Bank of India inspected the Bank on 14 October 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The Reserve Bank of India from time to time inspected the Bank. There was an inspection on 14 October, 1971.

facts.text: Inspection report referred to many irregularities and stated financial resources improved slightly.

anchor.surface_text: The report referred to many irregularities and stated that the financial resources of the Bank had improved slightly.

facts.text: Joint Registrar on 3 August 1972 forwarded the report to Registrar of Co-operative Societies and suggested action under section 54.

anchor.surface_text: The Joint Registrar on 3 August, 1972 forwarded the report to the Registrar of Co-operative Societies and suggested action under section 54 of the Act.

facts.text: Government issued notifications on 11 August 1972 reciting State gave Rs. 23.80 lakhs and necessary in public interest to take control.

anchor.surface_text: In this background the Government issued the impugned numberifications on 11 August, 1972. Broadly stated, the numberifications recited that the State had given Rs. 23. 80 lakhs to the Bank and it was necessary, in public interest to take powers to exercise companytrol over the companyduct of the business of the Bank to safeguard the public funds.

facts.text: Notifications allowed State to nominate 15 persons on Board, appoint President, VP, MD subject to govt control.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 54 of the Act should have the right to numberinate as its representatives, fifteen persons on the Board of Management and to appoint one among them as the President, one as the Vice-President and one other as the Managing Director of the Bank. The President, the Vice- President and the Managing Director under the numberification should exercise powers and discharge their functions subject to the supervision, direction and companytrol of the State Government.

facts.text: Second notification nominated fifteen persons to form Board of Directors; Deputy Commissioner Bellary appointed President.

anchor.surface_text: The second numberification numberinated fifteen persons to form the Board of Directors of the Bank. The Deputy Commissioner Bellary was appointed the President of the Bank.

facts.text: Bank challenged notifications on grounds: ultra vires the Act, violation of natural justice, political rivalry to remove President.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank challenged the numberifications on three grounds. First, the action of the Government was ultra vires the Act second, the action was bad in violation of principles of natural justice third, the action was taken because of political rivalry with an evil eye to remove the President from the office.

facts.text: High Court upheld first two contentions and set aside the notifications.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the first two companytentions and set aside the order.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed, upholding High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly set aside the impeached numberifications. For these reasons, the appeal fails and is dismissed. The State will pay companyts to the respondents.

facts.text: State aid to Bank more than two lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 of the Act provides that where State aid amounting to number less than two lakhs of rupees is given to any companyoperative society,

facts.text: Mysore High Court judgment dated 1 June 1973.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment dated 1 June, 1973 of the High Court of Mysore.
sections 54 and 121 Of the Mysore Co-operative Societies Act, 1959 hereinafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Joint Registrar on 3 August, 1972 forwarded the report to the Registrar of Co-operative Societies and suggested action under section 54 of the Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to take control over co-operative society receiving state aid not less than two lakhs in public interest

anchor.surface_text: The State Government in exercise of the powers conferred by section 54 of the Act should have the right to nominate as its representatives, fifteen persons on the Board of Management and to appoint one among them as the President,

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to take control over co-operative society receiving state aid not less than two lakhs in public interest

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 of the Act provides that where State aid amounting to not less than two lakhs of rupees is given to any co-operative society, the State Government, if it is satisfied that it is necessary in public interest so to do, may by notification in the official gazette take power to exercise such control over the conduct of business of such society as shall suffice in the opinion of the State Government to safeguard the interests of the State.

concepts.interpretation: Power exercised in public interest to exercise control sufficient to safeguard state interests; control means check, restraint, influence to regulate business conduct, not supersession or removal of committee or officers

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ciety. Section 30 further provides that the Registrar can manage the affairs of the society for such period or periods number exceeding two years. The

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to take control over co-operative society receiving state aid not less than two lakhs in public interest

anchor.surface_text: Section 121 enacts that the State Government may, by general or special order published in the official gazette, exempt any co-operative society or any class of societies from any of the provisions of this Act or may direct that such provisions shall apply to such society or class of societies with such modifications as may be specified in the order.

concepts.interpretation: Used to modify section 29 to allow nomination of 15 persons instead of max 3 or 1/3

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: take powers to exercise companytrol over the companyduct of the business of the Bank to safeguard the public funds. The State Government in exercise

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to exempt co-operative society from provisions of Act or apply with modifications

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, reference may be made to section 30 of the Act which provides for supersession of Committee. If, in the opinion of the Registrar, the Committee of any Co- operative Society persistently makes default or is negligent in the performance of the duties imposed on it by this Act or the, Rules or the bye-laws, or commits any act which is prejudicial to the interests of the society or its members, or is otherwise not functioning properly, the Registrar may, after giving the committee an opportunity to state its objections, if any, by order in writing, remove the committee and appoint a new committee consisting of one or more members of the society in its place or appoint one or more Administrators who need not be members of the society.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for supersession of committee after opportunity to show cause (natural justice); proper procedure for removal, not to be bypassed by s54

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: y or guaranteed the repayment of loans. The members numberinated by the Government under section 29 of the Act does number exceed three or one-third o

concepts.unlisted_description: Supersession of committee of co-operative society

anchor.surface_text: The notification further stated that section 29 which conferred power on the State Government subject to any notification under section 54 or section 121 to have the right to nominate as its representatives not more than three persons or one third of the total number of members of the Committee of the Cooperative Society, whichever is less would be modified by substituting the words have the right to nominate as its representatives 15 persons of the Committee of the Co-operative Society of whom one shall be appointed as Managing Director.

concepts.unlisted_description: Nomination by government of representatives on committee where state subscribes to share capital or guarantees loans; limited to 3 or 1/3

anchor.surface_text: Section 29 to which reference has already been made provides for the nomination by the Government of persons on the committee of the Society where the State Government has subscribed to the share capital of a co-operative society or guaranteed the repayment of loans. The members nominated by the Government under section 29 of the Act does not exceed three or one-third of the total number of members of the Committee, whichever is less.

concepts.unlisted_description: Nomination by government of representatives on committee where state subscribes to share capital or guarantees loans; limited to 3 or 1/3

anchor.surface_text: The Bank challenged the notifications on three grounds. First, the action of the Government was ultra vires the Act second, the action was bad in violation of principles of natural justice third, the action was taken because of political rivalry with an evil eye to remove the President from the office.
The second vice of the notification is that it is in violation of principles of natural justice. Section 30 of the Act contemplates a notice where the State intends to supersede the Management.

issues.text: Whether the impeached orders suffer from the infirmity that the entire committee of Management has been superseded by the notifications under section 54

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the impeached orders suffer from two insurmountable infirmities. One is that the entire committee of Management has been superseded. There is a provision under section 30 of the Act to supersede the management. The State Government does not take recourse to the don. Indirectly the State Government has overthrown- the Committee of Management including the President and the Vice-President. The President and the Vice-President are officers within the meaning of section 2 g  of the Act. Section 54 does not confer any power to remove the President and the Vice- President of the Society.

issues.text: Whether the notification is in violation of principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: The second vice of the notification is that it is in violation of principles of natural justice. Section 30 of the Act contemplates a notice where the State intends to supersede the Management.

arguments.claim: Section 54 contemplates exercise of control over the conduct of the business. The word control suggests check, restraint or influence

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 contemplates exercise of control over the conduct of the business. The word control suggests check, restraint or influence. Control is intended to regulate and hold in check and restrain from action.

arguments.claim: In the guise [of] exercising control the State has displaced the committee of Management and substituted its own Committee. The State has indirectly intended to achieve what it is directly prohibited from doing under section 54

anchor.surface_text: In the guise exercising control the State has displaced the committee of Management and substituted its own Committee. The State has indirectly intended to achieve what it is directly prohibited from doing under section 54 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The Committee has been deprived of their right to manage the affairs of the Society [arbitrarily and in utter defiance of the powers under the statute]

anchor.surface_text: The Committee has been deprived of their right to manage the affairs of the Society. They have been deprived of the right arbitrarily and in utter defiance of the powers under the statute.

holdings.text: The impeached orders suffer from the infirmity that the entire committee of Management has been superseded by the notifications under section 54, bypassing the specific provision under section 30.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the impeached orders suffer from two insurmountable infirmities. One is that the entire committee of Management has been superseded. There is a provision under section 30 of the Act to supersede the management. The State Government does not take recourse to the don. Indirectly the State Government has overthrown- the Committee of Management including the President and the Vice-President.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 30 provides specific mechanism for supersession after notice; s54 does not authorize direct or indirect overthrow of committee.

holdings.text: The President and the Vice-President are officers within the meaning of section 2(g) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The President and the Vice-President are officers within the meaning of section 2 g  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definition to facts.

holdings.text: Section 54 does not confer any power to remove the President and the Vice-President of the Society.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 does not confer any power to remove the President and the Vice- President of the Society.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s54 limits to control over business conduct, not personnel removal; harmonious with s30.

holdings.text: Section 54 contemplates exercise of control over the conduct of the business; control means check, restraint or influence to regulate, not supersession.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 contemplates exercise of control over the conduct of the business. The word control suggests check, restraint or influence. Control is intended to regulate and hold in check and restrain from action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual interpretation of 'control' distinguishes regulation from displacement of management.

holdings.text: In the guise of exercising control under section 54, the State cannot displace the committee and substitute its own, achieving indirectly what is directly prohibited.

anchor.surface_text: In the guise exercising control the State has displaced the committee of Management and substituted its own Committee. The State has indirectly intended to achieve what it is directly prohibited from doing under section 54 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents circumvention of statutory limits via indirect action.

holdings.text: The notification is in violation of principles of natural justice as section 30 requires notice before supersession of management.

anchor.surface_text: The second vice of the notification is that it is in violation of principles of natural justice. Section 30 of the Act contemplates a notice where the State intends to supersede the Management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deprivation of management rights without opportunity to be heard violates audi alteram partem under s30 procedure.

holdings.text: The Committee has been deprived of their right to manage arbitrarily and in defiance of statutory powers.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee has been deprived of their right to manage the affairs of the Society. They have been deprived of the right arbitrarily and in utter defiance of the powers under the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Action bypasses mandatory procedural safeguards in s30.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly set aside the impeached notifications; the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly set aside the impeached notifications. For these reasons, the appeal fails and is dismissed. The State will pay costs to the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of ultra vires and natural justice violations warrants quashing notifications and dismissing appeal.
